ai-iti110:0.3_0: The Chapter on the Holy Offering of the Teaching
ai-iti110:1.1_0: For this was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.
ai-iti110:2.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant—whether sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts—
ai-iti110:2.2_0: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.
ai-iti110:2.3_0: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.
ai-iti110:3.1_0: Suppose a mendicant were to give rise to sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.
ai-iti110:3.2_0: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.
ai-iti110:3.3_0: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.
ai-iti110:4.1_0: Suppose a mendicant who was sitting or malicious, or cruel thoughts arose.
ai-iti110:4.2_0: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.
ai-iti110:4.3_0: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.

ai-iti110:6.3_0: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when walking.
